Award.AwardTitle: Optical Analysis and Imaging of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor R. Bruce Weisman and his group at Rice University are devising methods to better characterize single-walled carbon nanotubes, which are among the most promising new materials emerging from nanotechnology research. These long molecular-sized tubes of chemically bonded carbon atoms display remarkable physical properties which promise advances in fields including high performance materials, nano-scale electronics, solar energy harvesting, and medical diagnostics and therapy. A barrier to realizing these applications is often the assortment of different nanotube structures - each with different properties - which result from nanotube synthesis. This project is developing and enhancing convenient and nondestructive optical nanotube analysis methods using near-infrared light. Novel instrumentation is being developed to enhance the speed and effectiveness of analysis, and to improve capabilities for physically sorting nanotube mixtures by structure. This work should enable progress in sorting nanotube samples according to length, an important goal for many applications.

The project provides valuable research experience to a number of undergraduate and graduate students. The analysis methods developed and refined will likely be incorporated into commercial scientific instruments. More broadly, the technical results of the project will also help overcome some of the obstacles that now hamper commercial production of nanotube-based devices and products. This may have a positive effect on the U.S. economy because of the substantial potential value of nanotube applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on improving optical methods for characterizing an important class of artificial nanomaterials called single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs). The remarkable physical properties of these SWCNTs make them of great interest for a wide range of real-world applications ranging from stronger and lighter automobile body parts to super-miniaturized electronics. However, SWCNTs are produced in a variety of structural forms, and for many applications it is necessary to either structurally sort them or at least analyze for how much of the different forms are present. Optical methods using visible and near-infrared light offer the most promising methods to guide sorting and characterize samples. 

During the project, we have accurately measured the absorption strengths of different SWCNT structures. This calibration information allows anyone to find the concentrations of specific SWCNTs using simple laboratory equipment. To simplify the purification of SWCNT samples, we invented a small and inexpensive magnetic device that can be used in place of expensive centrifuges. Measuring the lengths of SWCNTs has always been a tedious task for nanotube researchers. We developed a new method for length measurements in which a special fluorescence microscope is used to observe many individual nanotubes moving randomly (Brownian motion) in a liquid. For many samples, this method is preferable to the one that is normally used.One of the best ways to detect and analyze SWCNTs is through their fluorescence emission at near-infrared wavelengths. By studying hundreds of individual nanotubes, we found that the strength of this emission varied greatly even for nanotubes of the same size and structure, reflecting different levels of atomic-level defects. We also used optical methods to systematically study how nanotubes with chemical groups deliberately bonded to their sidewalls could be converted back to unperturbed nanotubes by heating at specific temperatures. Finally, we took the first step toward using SWCNT fluorescence for an important real-world application: monitoring distortions of key structural elements in aircraft, pressure vessels, pipelines, bridges, etc. Such strain measurements are widely needed in industry to ensure safe operation and avoid catastropic failures, but current technology for making strain measurements has serious limitations. We demonstrated that after a thin film of SWCNTs embedded in a plastic coating has been painted onto a surface of interest, the nanotubes act as tiny strain sensors because their fluorescence shifts in wavelength according to the strain in the surface. This allows us to make strain measurements on real objects using light rather than electrical connections, as with conventional sensors. We are optimistic that this novel application of SWCNT optical properties can be developed into a practical and valuable industrial technology.
